description.value:
Over 52 companies and institutions are based at Marineterrein, a former navy base still unfamiliar to many visitors. This interactive sign guides guests to locations, events, and provides real-time info like crowd levels and water temperature.

This info kiosk is interactive. Using a Touch Screen, visitors and guests can navigate the many actvities or find the organizations located throughout 4 hectare business park and living lab 

More Info Link: 
https://marineterrein.nl/

Data Link:
https://marineterrein.nl/te-doen/sporten/

Sound nuisance in the city is a big problem. Sensing and classifying sounds can provide the necessary information to understand moments, duration and types of nuisances like scooters, loud people, car doors, music, motorcycles, scooter alarm and more

OpenEars is sensor to classify sounds using Deep Learning. It is based on a RaspberriPi and a USB microphone (UMIK). The results of the classfication is send over MQTT tot the Sensemakers IoT Platform.

Links: 
Realtime Data: https://www.mt-dashboard.nl/admin/goto/BPaPUyxHk

The Husense sensor uses radar (MMwave) technology to anonymously monitor how people move through indoor and outdoor spaces. It provides real-time insights to improve safety, efficiency, and space usage—without using cameras or collecting personal data.

Using mmWave we can:

- Count the total number of visitors entering and exiting the Marineterrein
- Recognize behavior (walking, running, cycling, etc.)
- Provide busyness locations (heatmaps)
- Detect speeds of walkers, runners, and cyclists
- Show walking and cycling paths

LINKS:
Dashboard: https://portal.husense.io/area/b9c17619-be37-4c6a-a1f3-45e08fd3466c/dashboard/
Data: https://tapp.waw.cgntq.org/

Survision Nanopak & Nedap TRANSIT Ultimate

At Marineterrein, RFID and license plate scanner sensors manage vehicle access efficiently and securely. They help monitor traffic flow, authorize entry, and enhance safety by identifying vehicles automatically—minimizing congestion and supporting smart, transparent mobility in public space.

The long range RFID sensor reads tags from authorized vehicles using radio waves, while the license plate scanner uses optical recognition to identify plates—both enabling automated, contactless access control and vehicle tracking.

The sensor signage at Marineterrein informs visitors about nearby sensors, explaining their purpose and ensuring transparency. This initiative promotes public awareness and trust in smart city technologies while safeguarding privacy.

The sign promotes digital transparency in public space by showing what sensors are present, what data they collect, and why—using symbols, clear text, and QR codes linking to detailed online info.

Telraam Sensor

The Telraam sensor helps Marineterrein monitor street activity by counting cars, bikes, pedestrians, and more. It supports the city by giving a definition of "Autoluw' and helps with future urban planning, offering insights into traffic patterns to improve safety, accessibility, and the overall design of the Marineterrein.

Telraam uses a small window-mounted edge device that uses computer vision to accurately detect road users—like cars, bikes, and pedestrians—without identifying individuals, ensuring both accuracy and privacy.

link: https://telraam.net/en/location/9000006266

Public Eye

The PublicEye sensor helps Marineterrein understand how public spaces are used by anonymously measuring crowd density and movement. This data supports better planning, safety, and livability, while ensuring transparency and protecting the privacy of all visitors.

PublicEye uses optical sensors and edge processing to detect the number and flow of people in an area. It analyzes movement patterns anonymously, without storing personal data or video footage.

Delivery Drones (look up!)

Amsterdam Drone Lab The Amsterdam Drone Lab monitors and researches drone activity to ensure airspace safety in urban areas. By detecting unauthorized drones, it helps protect public events, sensitive zones, and supports responsible drone use in the city.

Amsterdam Drone Lab is crucial for managing urban airspace, preventing drone-related risks, and informing policy. It enables safe drone integration while protecting citizens, infrastructure, and privacy through research and detection technologies.

Listening To Our Cities

The "Listening to our Cities" project explores how urban sound impacts daily life. By capturing and analyzing soundscapes, it helps cities design healthier, more pleasant environments while raising awareness about noise and acoustic well-being.

The sensor records ambient sounds and classifies them (e.g., traffic, voices, birds) using AI. It focuses on sound types, not individual conversations, ensuring privacy while providing valuable acoustic insights.

Swimming Temperature

Since becoming an official swimming location in 2025, the Marineterrein has become a popular spot to cool off in summer or warm up in Kuuma saunas. In winter, cold-water swimmers practice the Wim Hof method here.

A water temperature sensor is located one meter below the surface, beneath the boardwalk. Using LoRa technology, it connects to the Marineterrein website and ABRI public info touchscreens at each entrance.
link: www.mt-dashboard.nl

The mmWave sensor as a fully-fledged, privacy-friendly alternative for monitoring crowd movements. It anonymously counts the number of people using radar technology. mmWave is a smart alternative to surveillance cameras. No images or videos are used in the data collection or processing.

ShutterCam

The ShutterCam explores how to responsibly use cameras in public spaces by making surveillance visible and transparent. It invites public input and shows when a camera is actively recording, promoting trust and accountability in urban sensing.

ShutterCam features a physical shutter that opens only during active recording. It clearly signals when surveillance is happening and collects minimal data, combining transparency with privacy-aware camera use in public spaces.

If you cannot measure it, you cannot improve it. With this adagium in mind, CITIXL, TAPP, and Amsterdam CTO collaborated to deploy smart cameras and visitor screens, to better manage the growing crowds at Marineterrein Amsterdam. The smart cameras count visitors which are anonymized and visualized on on-site screens, providing visitors with live information on the crowdedness per area and the current water quality. link: https://marineterrein.nl/en/experimenten/open-source-crowd-monitor/

When is a crowded public space too crowded? Is there a turning point at which visitors will no longer feel safe and are unable to move around freely? How do visitors anticipate their next visit when informed about the crowdedness in a public space?

The open-source crowd monitor will be tested for two months, and aims to identify the crowdedness and liveability of Marineterrein Amsterdam during the summer. link: www.mt-dashboard

Lightwell

There are 42 Smart Lights to improve urban lighting efficiency and safety on the Marineterrein. They automatically adjust brightness based on activity, reduce energy use, and can host additional sensors—enhancing public space monitoring and environmental data collection.

The smart lights use motion and ambient light sensors to dynamically adjust brightness. They can integrate air quality, noise, and traffic sensors, turning each light post into a multifunctional data and service hub.

Digitale Gracht

The Digital Grachten project uses smart sensors to monitor traffic flow on Amsterdam’s canals. It helps manage congestion, improve safety, and ensure sustainable use of the waterways—while respecting privacy and supporting transparent urban mobility solutions.

The RFID sensor identifies boats via onboard tags as they pass fixed checkpoints. It records movement data anonymously, helping monitor canal traffic patterns without tracking individuals or storing personal information.
